title: Can you solve the death race riddle? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of the protagonist in the story?

options.label: A
options.text: To win the Death Race across the Wastelands.

options.label: B
options.text: To rescue their uncle from the No-Side gang.

options.label: C
options.text: To repair the Coil Runner's thrusters.

options.label: D
options.text: To learn about the history of the Wastelands.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of triggering one of the three catastrophic failures?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The Coil Runner will be destroyed.

options.label: C
options.text: The protagonist will forfeit the Coil Runner and all its creations.

options.label: D
options.text: The protagonist will be given a second chance to participate in the race.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the thrusters and the catastrophic failures?

options.label: A
options.text: Each thruster can trigger two different effects.

options.label: B
options.text: Two factors can each independently lead to the same effect.

options.label: C
options.text: No effect is caused by two factors in conjunction.

options.label: D
options.text: The thrusters are not related to the catastrophic failures.

multiple-choice.question: What can be concluded from the fact that the Gravitometer spins in both cases mentioned in Slate's last two notes?

options.label: A
options.text: The spinning Gravitometer is the cause of the reactor leak.

options.label: B
options.text: The spinning Gravitometer is the cause of the Ignition explosion.

options.label: C
options.text: The spinning Gravitometer cannot be the cause of any particular malfunction.

options.label: D
options.text: The spinning Gravitometer is not related to the catastrophic failures.

multiple-choice.question: What can be concluded from the fact that the Fuel gauge glows in both the second and third test runs?

options.label: A
options.text: The B and C thrusters each independently make the Fuel tank glow.

options.label: B
options.text: The A, B, and C thrusters each make the Fuel tank glow.

options.label: C
options.text: The B and C thrusters make the Fuel tank glow together.

options.label: D
options.text: The A, D, and E thrusters make the Fuel tank glow together.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: A
options.text: He tried to push the eject button and get out

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: The Tower of Epiphany | Think Like A Coder, Ep 7

multiple-choice.question: How does Ethic program Hedge to figure out exactly how much energy each basin can hold?

options.label: A
options.text: By having Hedge count the total number of blocks in the basin.

options.label: B
options.text: By having Hedge look at the whole structure all at once.

options.label: C
options.text: By having Hedge consider a whole column of blocks at a time.

options.label: D
options.text: By having Hedge look at the individual cells one by one.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key insight that allows Hedge to calculate how much energy each basin can hold?

options.label: A
options.text: Each unoccupied cell will hold energy if and only if there is a wall eventually to its left, and a wall eventually to its right.

options.label: B
options.text: Each column can hold energy if and only if there is a wall eventually to its left.

options.label: C
options.text: Each column can hold energy if and only if there is a wall eventually to its right.

options.label: D
options.text: Each column can hold energy if and only if there is no wall eventually to its left.

multiple-choice.question: How many times does Hedge need to look at the individual stacks to calculate how much energy each basin can hold using the original algorithm?

options.label: A
options.text: N times

options.label: B
options.text: N+1 times

options.label: C
options.text: N-1 times

options.label: D
options.text: 3 times

options.label: A
options.text: Linear time

options.label: B
options.text: Quadratic time

options.label: C
options.text: Exponential time

options.label: D
options.text: Constant time

options.label: A
options.text: Hedge can look at the individual stacks one by one.

options.label: B
options.text: Hedge can look at the whole structure all at once.

options.label: C
options.text: Hedge can keep a running tally of the highest stack to its left.

options.label: D
options.text: Hedge can keep a running tally of the highest stack to its right.

multiple-choice.question: How many times does Hedge need to look at the individual stacks to calculate how much energy each basin can hold using the optimized algorithm?

options.label: A
options.text: N times

options.label: B
options.text: N+1 times

options.label: C
options.text: N-1 times

options.label: D
options.text: 3 times

multiple-choice.question: What is the time complexity of the optimized algorithm used by Hedge to calculate how much energy each basin can hold?

options.label: A
options.text: Linear time

options.label: B
options.text: Quadratic time

options.label: C
options.text: Exponential time

options.label: D
options.text: Constant time

title: Why do people fear the wrong things? - Gerd Gigerenzer

multiple-choice.question: What is risk?

options.label: A
options.text: The likelihood that an event will occur.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of people affected by an event.

options.label: C
options.text: The rate at which an event occurs.

options.label: D
options.text: The percentage of people who take a certain action.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between relative risk and absolute risk?

options.label: A
options.text: Relative risk is a percentage, while absolute risk is a rate.

options.label: B
options.text: Relative risk is a rate, while absolute risk is a percentage.

options.label: C
options.text: Relative risk expresses the likelihood of an event, while absolute risk expresses the number of people affected.

options.label: D
options.text: Relative risk expresses the number of people affected, while absolute risk expresses the likelihood of an event.

multiple-choice.question: A review in 2009 found that mammography screenings reduced the number of breast cancer deaths from five women in one thousand to four. What was the absolute risk reduction?
A new drug reduces the risk of heart attacks by 40%. What does this mean in terms of absolute risk?

options.label: A
options.text: The absolute risk of heart attacks drops from 1% to 0.6%.

options.label: B
options.text: The absolute risk of heart attacks drops from 0.6% to 0.4%.

options.label: C
options.text: The absolute risk of heart attacks drops from 1% to 0.4%.

options.label: D
options.text: The absolute risk of heart attacks drops from 0.4% to 0%.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relative risk reduction of a drug that reduces the risk of heart attacks by 40%?
What is the absolute risk of heart attacks in a group of 1,000 people who didn't take a new drug?
What is the absolute risk of heart attacks in a group of 1,000 people who took a new drug?
What is the relative risk reduction of a drug that reduces the risk of heart attacks by 40%?
What is the problem with expressing risk in relative terms?

options.label: A
options.text: It can be misleading.

options.label: B
options.text: It is always accurate.

options.label: C
options.text: It is never useful.

options.label: D
options.text: It is always necessary.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between expressing risk in absolute terms and expressing risk in relative terms?

options.label: A
options.text: Absolute risk is a rate, while relative risk is a percentage.

options.label: B
options.text: Relative risk is a rate, while absolute risk is a percentage.

options.label: C
options.text: C Absolute risk expresses the likelihood of an event, while relative risk expresses the number of people affected.

options.label: D
options.text: Relative risk expresses the likelihood of an event, while absolute risk expresses the number of people affected.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: To produce hormones and regulate body temperature.

options.label: C
options.text: To store fat and support the immune system.

options.text: To produce insulin and regulate blood sugar levels.

options.label: B
options.text: Autologous bone marrow transplant.

options.label: C
options.text: Bone marrow infusion.

options.label: D
options.text: Bone marrow extraction.

multiple-choice.question: How are blood stem cells typically extracted from a donor?

options.text: Through a needle directly into the bone marrow.

options.label: B
options.text: By circulating the blood through a machine that separates it into different components.

options.label: C
options.text: By extracting the marrow from a bone in the hip.

options.label: D
options.text: By taking a sample of blood from a vein.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of high doses of chemotherapy or radiation in a bone marrow transplant?

options.text: To kill the patient's existing marrow and make room for the new marrow.

options.label: B
options.text: To stimulate the production of new blood cells.

options.label: C
options.text: To weaken the immune system and prevent it from attacking the transplanted cells.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the risk of graft-versus-host disease.

multiple-choice.question: What is graft-versus-tumor activity?

options.text: A phenomenon where the transplanted cells attack the patient's organs.

options.label: B
options.text: A phenomenon where the transplanted cells help to eradicate cancer cells.

options.label: C
options.text: A phenomenon where the patient's immune system attacks the transplanted cells.

options.label: D
options.text: A phenomenon where the transplanted cells produce hormones.

multiple-choice.question: What is graft-versus-host disease?

options.text: A condition where the patient's immune system attacks the transplanted cells.

options.label: B
options.text: A condition where the transplanted cells attack the patient's organs.

options.label: C
options.text: A condition where the patient's immune system rejects the transplanted cells.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition where the transplanted cells produce antibodies.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of chemokines in a bone marrow transplant?

options.label: A
options.text: To stimulate the production of new blood cells.

options.label: B
options.text: To attract the transplanted cells to the bone marrow.

options.label: C
options.text: To weaken the immune system.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the risk of graft-versus-host disease.

options.label: B
options.text: Infection.

options.label: C
options.text: Organ failure.

options.label: D
options.text: Cancer recurrence.

options.label: D

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What are the four steps to an authentic apology, according to the author?
Why does the author believe that punishment alone is not enough to address men's violence?

options.label: A
options.text: Because punishment is too harsh and can harden individuals.

options.label: B
options.text: Because punishment does not teach individuals to change their behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: Because punishment is not effective in preventing future violence.

options.label: D
options.text: Because punishment is not a deterrent to future violence.

options.label: A
options.text: She wants them to be punished and imprisoned.

options.label: B
options.text: She wants them to apologize and change their behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: She wants them to forget about their past and move on with their lives.

options.label: D
options.text: She wants them to ignore their victims and move on.

options.label: A
options.text: Because men are the primary perpetrators of violence.

options.label: B
options.text: Because men need to take responsibility for their actions.

options.label: C
options.text: Because men can help create a process for healing and change.

options.label: D
options.text: Because men can provide financial support to victims.

options.text: She wants them to be ashamed and hide their past.

options.label: B
options.text: She wants them to be brave and be part of the transformation.

options.label: C
options.text: She wants them to forget about their past and move on with their lives.

options.label: D
options.text: She wants them to ignore their victims and move on.

multiple-choice.question: What does the author believe is the key to setting both victims and perpetrators free?

options.label: A
options.text: Punishment and imprisonment.

options.label: B
options.text: Apology and change.

options.label: C
options.text: Forgiveness and forgetting.

options.label: D
options.text: Ignoring the past and moving on.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a result of their lack of empathy.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a result of their suppressed feelings and emotions.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a result of their upbringing and environment.

options.label: A
options.text: She wants to see men punished and imprisoned.

options.label: B
options.text: She wants to see men change and take responsibility for their actions.

options.label: C
options.text: She wants to see men forget about their past and move on with their lives.

options.label: D

title: The ballet that incited a riot - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What event occurred at the first performance of Igor Stravinsky's "The Rite of Spring"?

options.label: A
options.text: The audience was very quiet and respectful.

options.label: B
options.text: The audience was so outraged that they drowned out the orchestra.

options.label: C
options.text: The ballet was a huge success and was performed multiple times.

options.text: The orchestra was very poorly received and was booed off the stage.

options.label: C
options.text: The sacrifice of a woman to bring about the change of seasons.

options.text: The struggle between good and evil.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

options.label: C

title: The Artists | Think Like A Coder, Ep 5

options.text: To provide a haven for people to follow their passions and take up crafts.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of a power outage.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the defenses of the tower.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of a natural disaster.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To deface each portrait with an X.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a new painting.

options.label: D
options.text: To repair a broken robot.

multiple-choice.question: What is the limitation of Hedge's painting processor?

options.text: It can only paint in one style.

options.label: C
options.text: It requires very specific instructions to paint an X.

options.label: D
options.text: It can only paint on a specific type of canvas.

options.label: A
options.text: He needs to paint in a spiral pattern.

options.label: B
options.text: He needs to paint in a typewriter-like pattern.

options.label: C
options.text: He needs to paint in a random pattern.

options.label: D
options.text: He needs to paint in a pattern determined by the length of the painting.

multiple-choice.question: What is the advantage of the typewriter approach to painting an X?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a more generalized solution.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a more simple solution.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a more efficient solution.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a more complex solution.

options.label: A
options.text: To look at a grid as a series of concentric squares.

options.label: B
options.text: To look at a grid as a series of random patterns.

options.label: C
options.text: To look at a grid as a series of identical squares.

options.label: D
options.text: To look at a grid as a series of different shapes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main drawback of the typewriter approach to painting an X?

options.label: A
options.text: It requires quite a bit of logic.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a more complex solution.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a more inefficient solution.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a more simple solution.

multiple-choice.question: What is the advantage of the spiral pattern approach to painting an X?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a more simple solution.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a more generalized solution.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a more efficient solution.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a more complex solution.

multiple-choice.question: What happens after Hedge rapidly defaces all of the portraits?

options.label: A
options.text: The garrison guarding the tower is alerted and prepares to attack.

options.label: B
options.text: The people in the forest become angry and start to riot.

options.label: C
options.text: The team is able to slip through the gorge and reach the tower.

options.label: D
options.text: The team is unable to slip through the gorge and is caught by the garrison.
